abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Guyana HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control Project, which
            presents existing data and information on the general
            characteristics of health care waste management system in
            Guyana; reviews and analyzes the institutional, legal, and
            regulatory health care system framework; and finally
            identifies problems and alternative solutions. The
            assessment of the health facilities shows that there is an
            adequate level of segregation, in-house handling, treatment,
            and ultimate disposal of most biomedical wastes, although
            there are gaps in management, equipment, incineration, and
            treatment that pose risks to the integrity of the overall
            system. This results in part from the system being derived
            from the application of general infection control practices,
            rather than practices that are specifically targeted or
            regulated. The situation will be improved and the risks
            mitigated by 1) improving the legal and regulatory
            framework, and expand the scope to include waste and
            residues transport and site disposal; 2) codifying practices
            to ensure that international standards apply; 3) clarifying
            management responsibilities; 4) training staff and
            developing their expertise in applying the new guidelines
            and protocols, and monitoring application; and 5) upgrading
            facilities and equipment (providing protective gear,
            trolleys, bins and containers, monitoring and recording
            equipment, fluid waste containers and piping, etc.); and
            reviewing need for inter-site transport of wastes,
            incineration, and disposal, to determine recommendations for
            investing in new incineration and disposal technology.
